title: Pebble Smartwatch: From $230 Million to Zero - Krazy Ken’s Tech Talk

Link below Pebble ignited the smartwatch revolution and grossed $230 MILLION in sales! But then it fizzled. What happened?  Smartwatch scam   What happened to Animusic 3?   Another flopped Kickstarter   iPhone 12 clone    Patreon!   Buy my Wallpaper Mega-Pack! They also got behind-the-scenes access, Discord VIP access, and their names in the credits! Pledge now to get those awesome perks, and help fund the future of the Computer Clan! Thanks for your support.  Read Eric's article and learn about Rebble!   Special thanks to Brad and Nick (the bystander who called me an IDIOT) for helping film this episode! Amazon links are powered by the Amazon Associates Program.  00:00 Introduction 00:48 Meet Eric and Allerta! 02:27 First Pebble Kickstarter! 04:16 Pebble Hardware 06:11 Pebble Software 09:29 Pebble Time! Now with Color! 13:28 Dipping Sales / New Kickstarter 15:22 Millions in Debt 16:57 The Rebble Alliance! 18:27 What Happened to Eric? 18:50 What (or Who) Killed Pebble? (Part 1) 20:08 What (or Who) Killed Pebble? (Part 2)  #KrazyKen #ComputerClan
transcript: - Pebble raised over $43 million on Kickstarter, smashing multiple records and propelling the world into the smartwatch revolution. But then they vanished. So what... or who killed them? Sponsored by Vessi. (upbeat music) Hey everyone, how are you all doing? If you're new here, welcome. My name is Krazy Ken and I never owned a Pebble back when it was new. I actually held out for the Apple Watch. But despite what watch you use, we all owe a great deal of gratitude to Pebble because without their innovations, products like the Apple Watch would probably be a year or maybe even a couple years behind. So let's take a look at Pebble's history and then we'll explore the products themselves, the hardware and the software. And then we'll see how and why this company went from hero to zero in only a matter of years. There's been several types of computer watches throughout history, like the WearComp Linux watch developed by Steve Mann in 1998. But the first big commercial success would be Pebble in 2013. And it all started with this man, Eric Migicovsky. Eric was a student at the University of Waterloo and he shared a watch concept that could display notifications from a smartphone. One of his earliest inspirations was a project request from his uncle in 2007. He asked Eric to hack a bedside clock so it could project BlackBerry emails on the ceiling. In 2008, Eric built a watch prototype using cell phone parts and an Arduino. And with some other students, Eric formed a new company named Allerta. Next year, they announced their first product, the Impulse smartwatch for BlackBerry devices. Oh yeah, BlackBerry, back when that was a thing. I mean, we can't really make fun of them, they had a good run. And the goal was simple, display notifications from your BlackBerry, Android or Symbian phone via Bluetooth. - That baby will do everything but tell you what time it is. - It doesn't tell time? - But Eric is an ambitious man, right? He had bigger fish to fry. He wanted to make a better version of Impulse that was compatible with iPhone because that was the number one request they received. Eric worked with designer Andrew Witte to make this all new watch. But like most things in life, you need money to make it happen. Eric pitched his new smartwatch to startup accelerator Y Combinator. And these guys mean business. You've likely used a product funded by YC before. Eric raised $375,000 through YC, but he needed more. So he sought out help from Kickstarter. Little did he know, he was about to make history. On April 11th, 2012, Allerta, now Pebble Technology, launched their campaign for the first Pebble smartwatch with a $100,000 goal. Okay, but I just gotta warn you, that's a big chunk of change. It may take you a while to hit it. Oh, okay, you raised the money in two hours. All right. Pledge to my Patreon- In the end, Pebble became one of the most funded Kickstarter campaigns in history. The Pebble started shipping to backers on January 23rd, 2013. And I tapped into his brain a little bit to learn more about these things. Because again, I'm a total novice with these. I never owned one before. So let's take a look at the hardware and the software and see what's up. (upbeat music) The Pebble featured a scratch and shatter resistant anti-glare plastic enclosure with swappable rubber watch bands. It came in three colors, Arctic White, Jet Black, and Cherry Red. The fourth color, Orange, was voted by backers. Pebble is water resistant with a five atmosphere rating, allowing for 50 meters of depth. So you can swim, dive, or shower without taking it off. And no, before you ask, I'm not gonna shower with it on camera. Not again, but I'll gladly swim with it. You know, okay, I thought it over. If y'all behave, I'll shower with it and test it out at the end of the episode. If you're good, do we have a deal? Now, originally the first Pebble actually wasn't supposed to be water resistant. Eric and the team added in that feature later because, you know, they have $10 million sitting here. They thought they would do something with it. And they listened to their community. There were a lot of suggestions on the campaign saying, please make it water resistant. So they listened. The display was 1.26 inches big and it used an ultra low power e-paper LCD manufactured by Sharp. It featured 144 by 168 resolution and one bit black and white graphics. The display used a transflective layer. So your environment's light illuminated the display which helped save power. But when necessary, there was a built-in backlight too. And this helped achieve Pebble's legendary seven-day battery life. I've talked to several owners and it seems like the battery is the most praised feature. And to charge the battery, you connect Pebble to a special USB cable with a magnetic attachment. Now let's take a closer look at the internal specs. Pebble used an ARM Cortex M3 CPU with 128 kilobytes of RAM and four megabytes of flash storage. Pebble also had a vibrating motor for alerts, a three axis accelerometer, a magnetometer and ambient light sensor. So you have all of these juicy gizmos and gadgets strapped onto your wrist. What do you do with them? That's where the software comes in. Pebble collaborated with Apple to make a special version of macOS that was compatible with smartwatches. No, not really. Just making sure you're still paying attention. Pebble ran its own operating system, Pebble OS, which was built on a customized version of FreeRTOS. FreeRTOS is a common real-time operating system used in microcontrollers and small microprocessors. So it works perfectly for a tiny watch. Pebble OS lets users view iPhone and Android notifications on their wrist via Bluetooth. That was the big feature. But it also allows custom watch faces, which can be installed from the user's phone via the Pebble app. I love using the Sonic one because it helps me go fast. Oh, and we can't forget about the classic Macintosh desktop. And the Pebble could run apps. It had a built-in cycling application. It had a built-in range finder. And we take that stuff for granted nowadays. Well, there was no app store yet, but you could still download third-party apps and watch faces from other sources. And Pebble provided developers with an SDK so they can make those cool things. On April 12th, 2013, three months after the Pebble started shipping to backers, Pebble launched the SDK to developers so they can make watch faces and apps. But there were some limitations. For example, third-party apps could not communicate with your phone. But on a May 16th update, Pebble SDK was renamed PebbleKit and support for two-way communication between Pebbles and phones was now supported with the AppMessage framework. While developers were working on all the cool watch faces and third-party apps, the Pebble team was working on a brand new 2.0 SDK. On February 3rd, 2014, Pebble launched this new SDK with APIs for Bluetooth messaging, background workers, accelerometer access, compass access, and JavaScript. And then one day later, boom, app store. Pebble launched a dedicated app store inside the Pebble app with over 1,000 applications and faces available on day one. Multiple partners like ESPN, Uber, Yelp, eBay, and GoPro joined forces with Pebble to get their apps on users' wrists. Okay, this is looking good. You have the SDK, you have the community, you have the partners, you have the centralized app store. Bam, now we're cooking. And if that wasn't enough, Pebble launched a new Pebble Steel. So if you wanted the Pebble experience with a more premium look and feel, this was for you. It was available in black matte and brushed stainless steel for $249. And it featured a Corning Gorilla Glass screen. By the end of 2014, Pebble sold nearly 1 million units. And according to May 2014 data, they garnered 35% of the market share. But now it's at 0%, rounding down a little bit. But how could that happen? How could that possibly happen? Well, hold on there, Eager McBeaver. I appreciate your curiosity. Now this Apple Watch launch date was one month after the Pebble Time campaign ended, so the clock was ticking. Pebble Time was slightly thinner and smaller than the original. And the case was curved so it could fit your wrist more ergonomically. The biggest difference you'll notice is the display, now capable of 64 colors. And it featured Corning Gorilla Glass. And time included a microphone for voice dictation. Pebble OS also received a big update with the new timeline feature, which lets users view past and future reminders, alarms, calendar events, weather, and more. In a December 15th software update, Pebble Time also featured Pebble Health for built-in activity tracking. And to charge the battery, instead of attaching magnetically to the side, you now attach magnetically to the back. And if you craved that sexy steel, you can have it. Pebble Time Steel launched on August 6th, 2015 for $249. But we're not finished yet. Meet Pebble Time Round. It's round. Time Round had the same features as Time, but with a two-day battery life instead of seven, but smaller design means smaller battery. Fair trade-off. Time Round used a round display, shocker, and a super small, thin, and light stainless steel body, achieving more of that classic timepiece look. Round was released to retailers on November 8th, 2015 for $249. The Moto 360 came out actually before the Apple Watch, and that had a round display. So things might start getting a little challenging. 2016 started rough.
